title: Enclosure Sizing & Layouts for White's Tree Frogs
author: Habitat Builder Team
excerpt: White's Tree Frog–specific enclosure sizing, branch placement for weight support, and zone planning to prevent obesity and stress.
description: White's Tree Frog–specific enclosure sizing, branch placement for weight support, and zone planning to prevent obesity and stress.

content.text: White's Tree Frogs are heavy-bodied and sedentary. The enclosure needs sturdy perches at multiple heights, a water bowl, shade, and basking zones—but avoid over-cluttering. Always size the enclosure for the adult frog from the start; upgrading enclosures causes stress and is unnecessary.

rows: Start with adult-sized enclosure from the beginning. This size is for ONE frog only. Upgrading causes unnecessary stress.
Heavy bodies need sturdy branches. Minimum 18×18×24 for a single frog.
Add 8-10 gallons (~30-40% volume increase) per additional frog. Ensure multiple basking perches to prevent competition.
Pairs need at least 24×18×30 to minimize stress. Extra height and width for courtship behavior and improved ventilation.

content.content: Multi-Frog Rule: Each additional frog needs ~30-40% more enclosure volume. Example: 2 frogs = 24×18×30", 3 frogs = 36×18×36" or larger. Overcrowding causes stress, aggression, and increased waste buildup.

items: Basking perch: Top-third, under UVB and heat, 82-86°F; easily accessible without climbing over obstacles.
Cool retreat: Mid-height shaded branch or hollow log on the opposite side for thermoregulation.
Water dish: Low and on the cool side, away from heat sources; easy access without navigating dense plants.
Partial open lanes: Allow movement between zones; too much clutter stresses White's and traps stale air.

content.text: Perch Weight Capacity Guidelines: White's Tree Frogs are heavy-bodied amphibians (40-80g adults, some reaching 100g+). Perches must support their weight without sagging or breaking.

items: Minimum branch diameter: 3/4 inch for juveniles, 1-1.5 inches for adults (60g+).
Weight test: Perch should support 2-3x the frog's weight without bending. Test by pressing down with similar force before introducing frog.
Anchor 2-3 main perches at different heights (30%, 60%, 85%) diagonally for varied viewing and thermal control.
Avoid: Thin bamboo, bendy vines, or lightweight plastic branches. These will sag under White's weight and cause stress.
Recommended materials: Natural hardwood branches (oak, manzanita), thick cork bark flats, magnetic ledges rated for 150g+.
Add one broad-leaf plant (pothos, ficus) for shade and humidity; avoid dense carpets that trap moisture.
Secure branches with aquarium-safe silicone, super glue, magnets rated for 200g+, or heavy-duty suction cups. Test all perches before introduction—White's are heavy and will stress weak anchors.

content.content: Installation Tip: Mount horizontal perches with a slight upward angle (5-10 degrees) to prevent frogs from sliding off during sleep. White's often sleep on exposed perches rather than hiding.

items: Perches only at the back: White's hide out of sight instead of basking; bring main branches forward.
Thin perches: Will sag under weight or snap; use sturdy branches rated for heavy-bodied amphibians.
Water bowl under heat: Creates humidity swings and mold; place on cool side.
Over-planting: Traps stagnant air; White's tolerate simple setups better than lush rainforest scenes.
Front-opening door for low-stress access and handling.
Basking perch under UVI 0.5-1.0 and 82-86°F heat; no obstacles between frog and heat/light.
Minimal but adequate shade (one plant or hide, not jungle-dense).
Sturdy anchors rated for weight; test all perches before introduction.
Clear path for daily water dish swap and weekly spot-cleaning.
